title: Multiple Vulnerabilities (Including SQLi) in love.uber.com
vulnerability_information:
Hi,
I noticed you are using a critically vulnerable version of  [WMPL](https://wpml.org/).

By accessing http://love.uber.com/wp-content/plugins/sitepress-multilingual-cms/changelog.md,
Attacker could find out http://love.uber.com/ is running WMPL version **3.1.8.4**

######Which is Vulnerable to,
1. SQL injection which gives full access to the WordPress database.
2. Page, post and menu deletion by an unauthenticated attacker
3. Unauthenticated administrative functions which may lead to RCE (remote code execution)
4. Cross Site Scripting (XSS)
    
###SOURCES:
* https://klikki.fi/adv/wpml.html
* https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2015-2791
* https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/36414/
* http://darkmatters.norsecorp.com/2015/03/16/four-wordpress-wpml-plugin-vulnerabilities-impact-400000-websites/

###FIX:
According to [Official WPML Security update](https://wpml.org/2015/03/wpml-security-update-bug-and-fix/),
System administrators should update to at-least **version 3.1.9** which was released on march 11th, 2015 to resolve these issues. 

looking forward!

activities.message:
Hey @siddiki, have you actually been able to exploit this SQL injection vulnerability to extract information from the backend database? (Same question for the rest of the vulnerabilities).

Looking into this now, will update shortly.
Ah I see, the XSS from your other report is in this Wordpress extension.

Yeah!
I've been able to execute the XSS issue. I tried the other XSS issue, but it's not working for me.
I've not tried SQLi or RCE as it may violate program rules. (it happened with me)
So, i decided to report straight away.

Thanks

After looking into this it appears that the SQL injection is not possible due to our OneLogin wall halting access to that functionality (if you are able to exploit it, please let us know). In regards to your comment about remote code execution I'm a bit confused. How could this vulnerability be used to get remote code execution? The ExploitDB link doesn't appear to mention RCE at all.

If i'm not mistaking, Jouko Pynn√∂nen (the researcher who found these vulnerabilities) mentioning about code execution on issue number 4 (Unauthenticated administrative functions) in his blog https://klikki.fi/adv/wpml.html

Ah it appears that he says:
```
An unauthenticated attacker could then execute any of the about 50 WPML ajax actions intended for administrators only. There is a lot of choice for manipulating or destroying data. For instance, it's possible to define a root html file which is evaluated as
```

but also says.

```
A default WordPress installation with only WPML installed apparently doesn't generate nonces for unauthenticated users, so this is probably not exploitable unless there are other plug-ins installed or the user can login. For example bbpress generates nonces for unauthenticated users.
```

So it appears that the admin access bypasses can only be done if you have a valid `nonce` token which is restricted to admins (to prevent CSRF, if I'm recalling correctly). So I don't believe this is exploitable in this case.

Let me know if I am missing something! Either way this is a bad deal and we'll work on getting this updated - the report is much appreciated and I'll be triaging this issue shortly (as well as your other one).

> So it appears that the admin access bypasses can only be done if you have a valid nonce token which is restricted to admins (to prevent CSRF, if I'm recalling correctly). So I don't believe this is exploitable in this case.

I reassessed his blog and I think you're right.

Please let me know the updates.

Always Happy to help :)
Thanks

Hi @mandatoryuber,
Any approximate timeline to fix this one?
Updating current plugin to higher or newest version will terminate both issues i believe.
We will likely be deleting this site, stay tuned
Awesome, thanks for the report, @siddiki!
Hey @siddiki! Thanks again for your patience. Since this is directly related to your report #117068 we are going to handle payout for the issue on that ticket.

@mandatoryuber
Hi,
This report was about multiple vulnerabilities (including a SQLi) in WPML plugin of love.uber.com

Today i saw a disclosed report of uber titled **SQLi in love.uber.com** (https://hackerone.com/reports/125181) and it looks like it was a duplicate of this report.
my report was created at Feb 18th, which was more than a month before the mentioned report #125181

I'm not 100% sure as that report is partially disclosed, but I'm confident that issue is a duplicate entry of this report.
i would really appreciate if you could reassess both issues to clear my doubt.

Looking forward!

@mandatoryuber @fletcher @notcollin 
Hello,
This is frustrating!
Please at-least response on this report, so know that you're looking into this one!

Really disappointing!
Working with **UBER** bug bounty program used to fun, unfortunately not anymore.
one of the few reasons to participate in this program was responsiveness of the security team, which is drastically missing these days.

I saw @jouko expressed his disappointment about the program too.
when you can't meet up to the expectations of [two top researchers out of your top Five](https://hackerone.com/uber/thanks), means you're not doing it right.
I guess I will not spend my time digging bugs for this program anymore!

I would really appreciate if you could disclose this report publicly, so i can share it with people out there!
Thanks
Hey @siddiki looking into this now it appears we might have dropped the ball on this one. Will get an update to you shortly.

I'm not sure I understand the complaint @siddiki. As confirmed by your comment on March 29th, you did not uncover an SQL injection vulnerability here. The report #125181 you are referencing is a different bug, unrelated to your report, that did result in an SQL injection issue. The only similarity is the domain on which it was discovered. Additionally, that bug was only paid out 3K due to our rules not being clear at that time that our rewards were maximums. It seems our only mistake was not making it clearer that this report did not contain any new issues that weren't covered by your previous XSS issue in #117068, which you were fairly paid out for. Let me know if I am missing something here.

I contacted the researcher who reported #125181. He confirmed me that his report was also about the wpml sql injection. He also agreed that my report was identical to his report and I was the first person to report the SQLi. The original author of the exploit (Klikki Oy) also confirmed that he also reported the same issue with database excerpts but his report was marked duplicate. Klikki also confirmed that I was the first person (among three of us)  who reported the issue and agreed that my description ( link to his blog post) was working and valid.

Uber need to shed some light here. Please have another look.

I contacted the researcher who reported #125181. He confirmed me that his report was also about the wpml sql injection. He also agreed that my report was identical to his report and I was the first person to report the SQLi. The original author of the exploit (Klikki Oy) also confirmed that he also reported the same issue with database excerpts but his report was marked duplicate. Klikki also confirmed that I was the first person (among three of us)  who reported the issue and agreed that my description ( link to his blog post) was working and valid.
@siddiki we'll take a look into this now, will update shortly.

As @zacmuber pointed out, the issue in this report was communication on our end. This should've marked as 'Duplicate' and not 'Resolved'. We apologize for the miscommunication and confusion here.

That being said, after reading the 4 links you sent and comparing to #125181 - we can confirm this report was the same WPML vulnerability (CVE-2015-2791). However, the key is that this report didn't provide enough actionable information for us to confirm the existence of SQLi - #125181 provided a PoC demonstrating the SQLi.

On our end, it appeared our authentication middleware was mitigating any exploit. We mentioned that in this report and you never updated us with more details or a PoC. See this comment from @mandatoryuber on Feb 17:
> After looking into this it appears that the SQL injection is not possible due to our OneLogin wall halting access to that functionality (if you are able to exploit it, please let us know).

Had you provided more actionable information, this report would've been eligible for bounty. It's the responsibility of the researcher to provide enough information for us to be able to make a determination - this report did not do that.

Our Program Guidelines were updated, unrelated to this issue, to address this exact situation:
> If we receive several reports for the same issue, we offer the bounty to the earliest report for which we had enough actionable information to identify the issue. We don't want to encourage people spamming us with vague issues in an attempt to be first.

Hope this clarifies things. We appreciate your reports and encourage you to keep bug hunting in the future.

After reviewing all the details of this ticket and discussing with the team, we recognize there was some communication mistakes on our end and as such are awarding $250.

We appreciate your time and effort in our bug bounty program and encourage you to continue bug-hunting in the future!

Thanks for accepting that there was some "communication mistakes" regarding this issue.
Really appreciated! 
But i don't understand why this $250 monetary rewards is given. This doesn't make a sense in anyway! 
I don't plan to take this reward, so i would go for a charity instead! 

And thanks for encouraging to do bug hunting in future. I'll surely do that. But not in UBER bug bounty program anymore as i mentioned before. 
Thanks

To @HackerOne team, 
Hi, I would like to donate the amount of #117080 to Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre (https://www.fb.com/skmch/) on behalf of Charity Hackers Association. 
Please contact Shahmeer Amir (shahmeerbond@gmail.com) if more information required. 

I'll create a support ticket also. 
Thanks

summaries.content: There seems to be some confusion here which is being worked out. We feel the summary provided by siddiki is inaccurate, please see the comment thread for more information.

Long story short.
This report #117080 was created @ **18th February 2016** - not eligible for a bounty.
A duplicate #125181 was reported by @iad @ **22nd March 2016** - Rewarded

About the comment, "Since this is directly related to your report #117068 we are going to handle payout for the issue on that ticket"
They never did. Monetary reward of $3000 paid for the XSS only! ($3000 is the standard payout for XSS in UBER because of their unclear bug bounty rules)

user.name: Mohammad Tarek Siddiki
user.bio: 5+ years of experience in penetration testing. Managed and successfully completed 100+ pentest projects.
